subtopics.title: Introduction to Sets
subtopics.content:
Introduction

The concept of sets forms the foundation of modern mathematics. A set is simply a well-defined collection of distinct objects, considered as a single entity. These objects are called elements or members of the set. Sets help us represent groups of numbers, symbols, or even real-life objects in a structured way.

For example:

The set of vowels in English: V = {a, e, i, o, u}

The set of natural numbers less than 5: N = {1, 2, 3, 4}

Sets are widely used in algebra, probability, relations, functions, computer science, and logic.

subtopics.title: Representation and Types of Sets
subtopics.content:
Representation of Sets

Roster/Tabular Form: Listing elements, e.g. A = {2, 4, 6, 8}

Set-builder Form: Describing property of elements, e.g. A = {x: x is an even natural number less than 10}

Types of Sets

  • Finite Set: Has a countable number of elements, e.g. {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}
  • Infinite Set: Has uncountable/infinite elements, e.g. N = {1, 2, 3, 4, …}
  • Null/Empty Set (∅): No elements, e.g. {x: x² = -1}
  • Singleton Set: Exactly one element, e.g. {0}
  • Equal Sets: Two sets are equal if they have identical elements.
  • Subset: A ⊆ B means every element of A is in B.
  • Power Set: The set of all subsets of a set. If A = {1, 2}, then P(A) = {∅, {1}, {2}, {1, 2}}.
  • Universal Set: The set containing all objects under consideration. Usually denoted as U.

subtopics.title: Venn Diagrams and Set Operations
subtopics.content:
Venn Diagrams

Venn diagrams are visual tools using circles to represent sets and their relationships (intersection, union, etc.).

Set Operations

  • Union (A ∪ B): Elements in A or B or both.
  • Intersection (A ∩ B): Elements common to both A and B.
  • Difference (A - B): Elements in A but not in B.
  • Complement (A′): Elements in universal set U but not in A.

subtopics.title: Properties of Set Operations
subtopics.content:
Properties of Set Operations

  • Commutative: A ∪ B = B ∪ A, A ∩ B = B ∩ A
  • Associative: (A ∪ B) ∪ C = A ∪ (B ∪ C)
  • Distributive: A ∩ (B ∪ C) = (A ∩ B) ∪ (A ∩ C)
  • De Morgan's Laws:
    • (A ∪ B)′ = A′ ∩ B′
    • (A ∩ B)′ = A′ ∪ B′

subtopics.title: Cardinality of a Set
subtopics.content:
Cardinality of a Set

The number of elements in a set is called its cardinality. For finite sets, if A = {1, 2, 3}, then n(A) = 3.

For union and intersection:

n(A ∪ B) = n(A) + n(B) - n(A ∩ B)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a set?
options: {x: x is an intelligent student in class}
questions.answer: {x: x is an intelligent student in class}
questions.explanation: The set of all intelligent students in class is not well-defined because 'intelligent' is subjective and not a precise criterion for membership in a set.

questions.question: What is the power set of A = {1, 2}?
questions.explanation: The power set of A contains all possible subsets of A, including the empty set and A itself. For A = {1, 2}, the subsets are: ∅, {1}, {2}, {1, 2}.

questions.question: If U = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} and A = {1, 2, 3}, what is A′?
questions.explanation: A′ (complement of A) contains all elements in the universal set U that are not in A. Since U = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} and A = {1, 2, 3}, A′ = {4, 5}.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.explanation: The union of any set A with the empty set ∅ is A itself, because the empty set contributes no elements. A ∩ ∅ = ∅, A - ∅ = A, and ∅ is a subset of every set.

questions.question: If A = {2, 4, 6} and B = {4, 6, 8}, what is A ∩ B?
questions.explanation: The intersection A ∩ B contains elements that are common to both A and B. The common elements between {2, 4, 6} and {4, 6, 8} are {4, 6}.

questions.question: Which of the following sets are equal?
questions.explanation: Sets are equal if they contain exactly the same elements, regardless of order. {1, 2, 3} and {3, 2, 1} contain the same elements, so they are equal.

questions.question: If A ⊆ B and B ⊆ A, then:
questions.explanation: If A is a subset of B and B is a subset of A, then every element of A is in B and every element of B is in A, which means A and B have exactly the same elements. Therefore, A = B.

questions.question: What is the complement of the universal set U?
questions.explanation: The complement of the universal set U contains all elements that are not in U. Since U contains all elements under consideration, there are no elements outside U, so U′ = ∅.

questions.question: If A = {1, 2} and B = {2, 3}, what is A ∪ B?
questions.explanation: The union A ∪ B contains all elements that are in A or B or both. A = {1, 2} and B = {2, 3}, so A ∪ B = {1, 2, 3}. Note that each element appears only once in a set.

questions.question: What is the cardinality of the empty set ∅?
questions.explanation: The cardinality of a set is the number of elements in the set. The empty set ∅ contains no elements, so its cardinality is 0.
